Although the study uses task-evoked fMRI in a healthy adult sample (N=36, ages 20–35) and addresses vocal emotional processing (a form of social communication), it does not report any group-level univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps or coordinate tables/generalizable voxelwise contrasts for the healthy group. The paper presents ROI-based functional connectivity and graph-theoretical/network analyses (Power-264 atlas, OMST filtering, FC metrics) rather than whole-brain voxelwise activation results. This fails the explicit inclusion requirement for at least one group-level whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical map, so the study must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI task involved social-related processing (perception/understanding of others; implicit bias and responses to facial disfigurement). Sample includes a healthy adult group (N=31, ages 18–35) reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (pre- vs post-treatment faces) with familywise-error correction and cluster thresholds; results are described in text, figures, and tables. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, not restricted-age subgroup only). Therefore eligible for inclusion.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=21, ages 18–35) investigating social interaction perception using task paradigms (viewing dyadic and alone interaction videos) during fMRI. The study reports whole-brain GLM estimation and group-level whole-brain analyses for functional localizers (interaction > scrambled, bodies > objects, faces > objects, mentalizing > pain) used to define ROIs and provides whole-brain searchlight results; these constitute group-level, task-evoked univariate whole-brain analyses in a healthy sample. The task is clearly social (perception/understanding of others, social interaction). No exclusion criteria apply (not an ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only paper, healthy adults included and reported). Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (cyberball social exclusion) in healthy adult participants (N=71 females, age 21.7 ± 2.3), meeting the sample criterion (healthy adults 17–65). The study reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (initial whole-brain threshold p<0.001 uncorrected with clusters surviving FWE correction via small-volume correction) and provides peak coordinates and statistical maps for group-level contrasts. The task probes social-affiliation/ostracism and results are reported at the group level for healthy participants (within- and between-group contrasts across healthy subgroups). Although the sample is female-only (limits generalizability), the paper reports whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and thus satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using a socioemotional Face Processing Task (fearful vs. neutral faces) targeting social cognition/empathy. Sample: 49 healthy adults (ages 18–33), meeting the age and healthy-sample criteria. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (F > N and N > F contrasts) with TFCE/FWE correction, coordinates, figures and exploratory whole-brain analyses clearly attributed to the healthy group. It also includes ROI and connectivity analyses, but not exclusively; whole-brain activation maps are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants and examines face perception (a social-related process), the full text presents analyses focused on ROI-based multivariate pattern analyses (MVPA) and regression of behavioral models onto ROI/probabilistic visual-field masks. The paper does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (e.g., a whole-brain GLM contrast) for the healthy/control group in the main text or figures/tables described; instead results are reported for predefined ROIs and probabilistic visual field regions. Therefore it fails the review’s requirement for at least one clearly reported whole-brain univariate task activation map and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (real-time mutual eye contact), using a task probing social communication/attention. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (initial N=34; fMRI analyses reported on 30 participants; mean age ~21.7, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (LIVE > REPLAY; LIVE and REPLAY > REST) analyzed with random-effects GLM, cluster-level FWE correction, and tables/figures of significant clusters. Although connectivity and interbrain synchronization analyses are also reported, the study clearly includes whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group rather than only ROI or connectivity-only results. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI hyperscanning study in 44 healthy adult participants (mean age 22.4) using a social interactive task (pattern game) manipulating cooperation/competition and turn-based vs concurrent interaction. The authors report group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (GLM, FLAME) with non-parametric permutation correction and present cluster-level results and t-maps/coordinates for contrasts among conditions, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Sample falls within 17–65 and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (trustworthiness/fear appraisal of faces). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=17; ages 18–45) with results reported separately alongside a BPD group. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (group-level mixed-effects analyses, task contrasts such as trustworthiness>fearfulness and fearfulness>trustworthiness) and provides peak coordinates and cluster results (e.g., MNI peaks, Supplementary Tables), not only ROI findings. Whole-brain contrasts and group comparisons are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. It does not violate exclusion criteria (not limited to ROI-only, not only connectivity, includes healthy adult whole-brain maps). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (participants aged 18–22). The task is social (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma; assesses responses to cooperation/defection—perception/understanding of others, social interaction). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (GLM; cluster-based thresholding, Z-statistics, reported clusters/tables and figures) for healthy participants and also reports ROI analyses. Results for healthy/control groups are clearly described and generalizable within the adult sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes whole-brain task-evoked maps). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma probing cooperation/trust), enrolled healthy adult participants (N=20 males, age range 21–37), and reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task-evoked group-level results (one-sample t-tests, flexible factorial analyses; FWE cluster-corrected maps and tables of activations). Healthy-group effects are reported and generalized to the healthy sample (not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses). No exclusion criteria are violated (not an ROI-only, resting-state, or non-empirical paper; ages within 17–65). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

The study uses fMRI during naturalistic movie viewing (Toy Story), a stimulus with clear social-cognitive demands (theory of mind, social interactions). The sample includes a healthy adult group (final N=21 adults) within the target age range and reported adult-group results separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level statistical maps of inter-subject correlation (within-group inter-SC maps and Adult vs. Child contrasts) with multiple-comparison correction and peak coordinates, which are whole-brain task-evoked effects generalizable to healthy adults. Although the analysis uses inter-subject correlation rather than a traditional GLM, the reported group-level voxel/nodewise statistical maps satisfy the criterion of whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy/control group. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social feedback task (social inclusion/exclusion) in a healthy sample (N=56 analyzed; ages 17–20), which falls within the review’s adult range (17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (positive>neutral, negative>neutral, conjunctions) with voxelwise familywise-error correction and provides peak coordinates and conjunction maps. Analyses are reported for the healthy cohort (results not limited to a narrow subgroup), and are not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Participants are adolescents (N=34; ages 14–18, mean 16.3). Inclusion criterion requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65 or a separately reported adult subgroup. This study does not report a separate adult (≥17) healthy group or analyses restricted to adults, and the sample is predominantly under 17. Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social reward and reports whole-brain group-level results (cluster coordinates in social-processing regions), the participant age range violates the sample inclusion criterion. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social evaluation/impression formation (social-meaningful, social-irrelevant, non-social conditions). It reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate contrasts (social vs non-social; social-meaningful vs social-irrelevant) with corrected cluster thresholds and tables/figures of peak coordinates for the healthy participant groups. A healthy younger adult group (age 20–29) is analyzed and reported separately, meeting the 17–65 age requirement. The paper does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and presents whole-brain task activation maps/generalizable effects for the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria appear violated.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (impression formation of others varying by race and socioeconomic status), conducted in healthy adult participants (60 adult males, mean age 23.8). The task is a task-evoked, event-related impression-formation paradigm using faces (social-related processing). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain second-level GLMs and exploratory whole-brain regression results (clusters for the main effect of status and a VMPFC cluster), in addition to ROI analyses. Whole-brain task activation maps/coordinates are described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (only ROIs, only connectivity, non-healthy sample, or no whole-brain maps) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.
